s.text: The assumption is that private investors who buy and sell won are depressing its value below its equilibrium rate.
The effort to convert won into dollars and other foreign currencies depressed the value of the won, despite the Korean government's efforts to sustain it by using its reserves.
Companies that could pay their foreign debts when a dollar cost 900 won could not pay when a dollar cost 1,400 won.
Companies that could pay their foreign debts when a dollar cost 900 won could not pay when a dollar cost 1,400 won.
The assumption is that private investors who buy and sell won are depressing its value below its equilibrium rate.

The assumption is that private investors who buy and sell won are depressing its value below its equilibrium rate.
The exchange rate would have been higher, and the deficit larger, if the government had not been buying dollars with won, and in the process accumulating a reserve of dollars.
These equalities are maintained by variations of the exchange rate, interest rates, inflation rates, and real incomes.
These equalities are maintained by variations of the exchange rate, interest rates, inflation rates, and real incomes.
But it is equally probable that few people who read the daily paper, even those who read the financial pages, have a model of the international financial system in mind.
Most importantly, they will not understand the function of the external funds being provided by the International Monetary Fund and some countries, or where the whole process is heading.

But it is a story that fits into standard economic analysis, is coherent and understandable, and reveals the interaction among the forces at work--the kind of story I miss when I read the daily reports.
